Articles.Content: Does anyone know the Ksp value of sodium chloride? I need help ASAP! I've already got my calculated experimental Ksp value, but I need to know the actual theoretical Ksp value so I can find the percent error.
Not sure what this is about. Could you clarify your question, please?

Seems like he means the solubility product constant ... K\_sp

[http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu/Physical_Chemistry/Equilibria/Solubilty/Solubility_Product_Constant,_Ksp](http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu/Physical_Chemistry/Equilibria/Solubilty/Solubility_Product_Constant,_Ksp)

That acronym really needs clarification, especially on a KSP forum.

Incidentally, I'm of absolutely no help. Sorry to have wasted your time.

KSP doesn't NaCl. Really, failing is part of the game and rarely too annoying.

edit: Nvm, to meta.

Blame google for this, as inferring from his small post count I think that he is searching google for Ksp value and google returns KSP forums as top search result, then he searched for forum section that is most relevant to him, which is The Science Lab, and he registered in it... 

But its alright qdhuasheng, there are a lot of awesome discoveries in this world that the inventors stumble upon, like dynamite, slinky or X-rays or even peanut butter, and Kerbal Space Program is also one of them, spend some time in this forum and you will discover that Kerbal Space Program is an awesome game that can teach you space physics ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

K<sub>sp</sub> (NaCl) is around 37.5. It's quite high because of large solubility of sodium chloride.

You can find it on Google if you remove all references to Kerbal Space Program by including -kerbal into the search field.
